body.p: A callout is a string of text inside a graphic and is connected to a specific location in a document by a line. In , they are used to present comments and tracked change modifications. The callouts are decorated with a colored border and also have a colored background. The horizontal line that connects the callouts to their corresponding text fragments has the same color as the border.

section.title: Displaying Callouts in Author Mode
section.p: The callouts are displayed in the right side of the editing area in Author mode. assigns an individual color for the callouts depending on the user who is editing the document. To customize the list of these colors, and go to Editor Edit Modes Author Review . This Review preference page allows you to configure the colors for tracked change insertions or deletions, or for comments. You can choose to use the same color for all changes of that particular type of change, regardless of who makes the change. To do this, select the Fixed option for the particular type of change and choose a color from the color box. If the Automatic option is selected, automatically assigns a color based upon the Colors for automatic assignment list.

p.note: displays callouts only if View All Changes/Comments or View Only Changes/Comments by is selected in the Track Changes Visualization Modes drop-down menu. does not display callouts in View Final and View Original modes.

section.p: In some cases, the text you are editing can span into the callouts area. For example, this situation can appear for callouts associated with wide images or space-preserve elements (such as a codeblock element in DITA or programlisting in DocBook) that contain long fragments. To help you view the text under the covered area, applies transparency to these callouts. When the cursor is located under a callout, the transparency is enhanced, allowing you to both edit the covered content and access the contextual menu of the editing area.

section.title: Type of Callouts in
section.p:
uses callouts to provide an enhanced view of the changes that you or other authors make to a document. They hold specific information depending on their type. In addition, uses callouts to display comments that you associate with fragments of the document you are editing. For more information about editing comments, see the Managing Comments topic. To enable callouts, and go to Editor Edit Modes Author Review Callouts . This Callouts preferences page allows you to enable the following types of review callouts:
Comments - displays comment callouts when you insert a comment. You can use two types of comments in :
Author Review Comments - Comments that you associate with specific fragments of text. To insert this type of comment, select the content and use the Add Comment action that is available on the toolbar (or in the Review submenu of the contextual menu).
Tracked Changes Callout Comments - Comments that you add in an already existing tracked change insertion or deletion callout. To insert this type of comment, right-click the callout and select Comment Change. By default, the fragment of text that you comment is highlighted and a horizontal line connects it with the comment callout. A comment callout contains the name of the author who inserts the callout and the comment itself. To customize how comments are displayed, , go to Editor Edit Modes Author Review Callouts . For example, you can enable the Show review time option to include timestamp information in the callouts.
Comment Callouts
Track Changes deletions - When the Track Changes feature is enabled, displays deletion callouts when you delete a fragment of text. By default, a deletion callout contains the type of callout (Deleted) and the name of the author that makes the deletion. You can customize the content of a deletion callout to display the deleted fragment itself. To do this, , go to Editor Edit Modes Author Review Callouts , and enable the Track Changes deletions and Show deleted content in callout options. You can also enable the Show review time option to include timestamp information in the callouts.
Deletion Callouts
Track Changes insertions - When the Track Changes feature is enabled, displays insertion callouts when you insert a fragment of text. By default, an insertion callout contains the type of callout (Inserted) and the name of the author that makes the insertion. You can customize the content of an insertion callout to contain the inserted fragment itself. To do this, , go to Editor Edit Modes Author Review Callouts , and enable the Track Changes insertions and Show inserted content in callout options. You can also enable the Show review time option to include timestamp information in the callouts.
Insertion Callouts

section.title: Callout Contextual Menu Actions
section.p:
The following actions are available in the contextual menu of an insertion or deletion callout:
Accept Change - Select this option to accept the changes you or other authors make to a document.
Reject Change - Select this option to reject the changes you or other authors make to a document.
Comment Change - Select this option to comment an existing change in your document. You are also able to add a comment to a change from the Comment Change button available on the Review toolbar.

The following options are available in the contextual menu of a comment callout:
Edit Comment - Select this option to modify the content of a comment callout.The text area is disabled if you are not the author which inserted the comment.
Remove Comment - Select this option to remove a comment callout.

section.title: Selecting Callouts
section.p: To select a callout, either click the callout or its source. Selected callouts have a more intense background and a bold border. The connecting line between the source and the callout is also rendered in bold font. If you select a fragment of text that is associated with one or more callouts, the callouts are highlighted.

section.title: Printing Callouts
section.p: When you print a document from , all callouts that you or other authors have added to the document are printed. For a preview of the document and its callouts, go to File Print preview .
